audio_caption: The clip begins with a brief sound like a car door slamming shut, followed by a male speaker, who sounds somewhat instructional, introducing GPS Prune. He elaborates on the program's functionalities, explaining its use for route preparation and navigation. The clip concludes with an unintelligible "hmm."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a GPS program showing a map that can be dragged and zoomed. He says they'll use Wikipedia to find a mountain called "Harder" and check its difficulty. He mentions searching for the name online to verify and then loading it into the GPS program as a waypoint. He adds they can double-click the map to zoom in and find the nearest train station. The speaker then states they'll start drawing.

The audio begins with a speaker stating, "I'd like to change the maps." They then describe wanting to switch to an official Swiss map because it "shows the hiking routes nice and clearly." The speaker comes across as informative and helpful. There is only one male speaker present in the audio clip.

A single male speaker explains how to draw a track from a station to the top of something, noting the use of the right-click menu and that accuracy can be improved later. He suggests doing it carefully but emphasizes the need for just a "rough shape" now and that all points created have no altitude, so the profile view stays empty. He then says, "Okay".

A man speaks in a conversational tone, indicating that they can now look up altitudes to see the profile. The same man continues, noting that the distance is about 4 kilometers and the climb is around 750 meters, deeming it doable. He mentions that these numbers might increase as details are added later. He then plans to mark the top funicular station as an option for the way down and explains that adding a name to a point will make it a waypoint with a different symbol in the list.

The audio clip features a male speaker explaining how to activate edit mode using the hand icon in a window to add detail to a line for more accurate measurements. The speaker describes dragging points, adding detail, and focusing on key junctures. He then notes that inserting new points creates altitude value gaps, and itâ€™s most important to add points at track junctions. The clip ends with the speaker stating, "Okay, that looks better", explaining that an altitude lookup fills the gaps, increasing distance and climb.

A male speaker enthusiastically suggests showing "the root in 3D." He adds an extra point further up the ridge to include it in the 3D view. He starts the 3D view, mentioning options to control its appearance, like terrain and map images. He describes choosing a resolution and fetching altitudes to draw the terrain. The speaker describes the process as "pretty cool." He notes that the 3D view gives a good impression of the ridge's shape and allows looking from different directions, aiding in finding alternative routes. The speaker says they can use an "undo function" to delete the extra point. The speaker then asks about starting the hike from a bus stop, checking if it would make much of a difference, he concludes that it saves a kilometer but doesn't reduce the climb, so they should stick with the train station route.

The audio clip begins with a speaker instructing someone to turn off "edit mode" to avoid "dragging points by accident," spoken in a helpful tone. Then, another speaker, also in a conversational tone, asks "And what will we be able to see from the top?"

The clip starts with a person, presumably a male speaker, recommending the use of a "peak finder" tool which opens in a browser window. He explains how to use it to identify visible mountains from a selected viewpoint. He then directs attention to the view on the screen, zooming out, describing the scene as "great," and mentioning seeing along the lake. He concludes by identifying the Eiger mountain to the south.

The audio clip features two speakers, one male and one female, engaged in a conversation. The male speaker wonders aloud about the weather forecast. The male speaker then says, "Again from the online menu, we can ask OpenWeatherMap for a forecast." He notes, "That actually looks a little cold," and acknowledges that it's useful information. The audio ends with a brief musical interlude.

The audio features two speakers, a man speaking first and another man replying with a question, "What else?". They then discuss looking for geocaches using opencaching and accessing details in a separate browser window. The second man comments on a virtual cache that seems interesting because you have to find a sign at the top. They decide to add the cache coordinates as a waypoint and include a comment. Finally, the first man confirms that the track is ready. There is a soft clicking sound near the end.

The audio clip begins with a man speaking in an instructional tone, explaining how to export a track as a GPX file and store it on a GPS receiver. He emphasizes naming and saving the file in the correct directory. Then he notes the file is saved and says, "and that's it". Following this, he continues by mentioning preparing the track, measuring distances and climbs, using online resources, and saving the track onto the GPS receiver. Lastly, he concludes with "thanks for watching." The audio clip ends.
